A good name <FI>is<Fi> better than precious ointment; and the day of death than the day of one's birth.
<FI>It is<Fi> better to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting: for that <FI>is<Fi> the end of all men; and the living will lay <FI>it<Fi> to his heart.
Sorrow <FI>is<Fi> better than laughter: for by the sadness of the countenance the heart is made better.<RF>Sorrow: or, Anger<Rf>
The heart of the wise <FI>is<Fi> in the house of mourning; but the heart of fools <FI>is<Fi> in the house of mirth.
<FI>It is<Fi> better to hear the rebuke of the wise, than for a man to hear the song of fools.
For as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so <FI>is<Fi> the laughter of the fool: this also <FI>is<Fi> vanity.<RF>crackling: Heb. sound<Rf><CM>
Surely oppression maketh a wise man mad; and a gift destroyeth the heart.
Better <FI>is<Fi> the end of a thing than the beginning thereof: <FI>and<Fi> the patient in spirit <FI>is<Fi> better than the proud in spirit.
Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry: for anger resteth in the bosom of fools.
Say not thou, What is <FI>the cause<Fi> that the former days were better than these? for thou dost not enquire wisely concerning this.<RF>wisely: Heb. out of wisdom<Rf><CM>
Wisdom <FI>is<Fi> good with an inheritance: and <FI>by it there is<Fi> profit to them that see the sun.<RF>good…: or, as good as an inheritance, yea, better too<Rf>
For wisdom <FI>is<Fi> a defence, <FI>and<Fi> money <FI>is<Fi> a defence: but the excellency of knowledge <FI>is, that<Fi> wisdom giveth life to them that have it.<RF>defence: Heb. shadow<Rf>
Consider the work of God: for who can make <FI>that<Fi> straight, which he hath made crooked?
In the day of prosperity be joyful, but in the day of adversity consider: God also hath set the one over against the other, to the end that man should find nothing after him.<RF>set: Heb. made<Rf>

All <FI>things<Fi> have I seen in the days of my vanity: there is a just <FI>man<Fi> that perisheth in his righteousness, and there is a wicked <FI>man<Fi> that prolongeth <FI>his life<Fi> in his wickedness.
Be not righteous over much; neither make thyself over wise: why shouldest thou destroy thyself?<RF>destroy…: Heb. be desolate?<Rf>
Be not over much wicked, neither be thou foolish: why shouldest thou die before thy time?<RF>before…: Heb. not in thy time?<Rf>
<FI>It is<Fi> good that thou shouldest take hold of this; yea, also from this withdraw not thine hand: for he that feareth God shall come forth of them all.
Wisdom strengtheneth the wise more than ten mighty <FI>men<Fi> which are in the city.
For <FI>there is<Fi> not a just man upon earth, that doeth good, and sinneth not.
Also take no heed unto all words that are spoken; lest thou hear thy servant curse thee:<RF>take…: Heb. give not thine heart<Rf>
For oftentimes also thine own heart knoweth that thou thyself likewise hast cursed others.<CM>
All this have I proved by wisdom: I said, I will be wise; but it <FI>was<Fi> far from me.
That which is far off, and exceeding deep, who can find it out?

I applied mine heart to know, and to search, and to seek out wisdom, and the reason <FI>of things<Fi>, and to know the wickedness of folly, even of foolishness <FI>and<Fi> madness:<RF>I applied…: Heb. I and mine heart compassed<Rf>

And I find more bitter than death the woman, whose heart <FI>is<Fi> snares and nets, <FI>and<Fi> her hands <FI>as<Fi> bands: whoso pleaseth God shall escape from her; but the sinner shall be taken by her.<RF>whoso…: Heb. he that is good before God<Rf>
Behold, this have I found, saith the preacher, <FI>counting<Fi> one by one, to find out the account:<RF>counting…: or, weighing one thing after another, to find out the reason<Rf>
Which yet my soul seeketh, but I find not: one man among a thousand have I found; but a woman among all those have I not found.
Lo, this only have I found, that God hath made man upright; but they have sought out many inventions.<CM>
